required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Examination of a New Irrigation System for Transanal Irrigation in Children With Fecal Incontinence
clinical_study.official_title: Examination of a New Irrigation System for Transanal Irrigation in Children With Fecal Incontinence

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to investigate if a new irrigation system for transanal irrigation (TAI) is effective and more tolerable than the currently used system at the Pediatric Ward at Aarhus University Hospital.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a randomized, controlled study.
This study will be performed at Aarhus University Hospital (Denmark) and Aalborg University Hospital (Denmark) following the same protocol.
According to the initial randomization, children will be allocated to treatment with the new system (group A) or with the currently used system (group B). After a period of 6 weeks the child will crossover to use the contrary system.
The hypothesis is that A TAI system specifically developed for children will enhance the child's toleration of irrigation due to fewer reports on pain at insertion which will lead to better compliance. This outcome will induce a comparable or better effect on their fecal incontinence and reduce the needed follow-up period due to fewer incontinence relapse.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The children will use either the old or the new cone for transanal irrigation for 6 weeks and then crossover to the contrary cone.

primary_outcome.measure: The effect on fecal incontinence episode frequency
Evaluation of discomfort and on pain assessed on a Visual Analog Scale

secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated by home recordings and transabdominal rectal ultra sound.

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of compliance assessment using the different systems
Estimation in changes of the child's well-being
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated by home recordings using WHO-5

arm_group.arm_group_label: Newly developed cone for 6 weeks the currently used cone for 6 weeks
arm_group.description: Starts off with treatment with the newly developed cone for transanal irrigation for 6 weeks and are then instructed to crossover to the contrary system, the currently used, for additional 6 weeks.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Currently used cone for 6 weeks the newly developed cone for 6 weeks
arm_group.description: Starts off with treatment with the currently used cone for transanal irrigation for 6 weeks and are then instructed to crossover to the contrary system, the currently used, for additional 6 weeks.

intervention.description: Newly developed cone in a softer material and a design matching the use for transanal irrigation.
intervention.arm_group_label: Currently used cone for 6 weeks the newly developed cone for 6 weeks
Newly developed cone for 6 weeks the currently used cone for 6 weeks

intervention.description: Cone currently used for transanal irrigation at the Pediatric Ward, Aarhus University Hospital.
intervention.arm_group_label: Currently used cone for 6 weeks the newly developed cone for 6 weeks
Newly developed cone for 6 weeks the currently used cone for 6 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Fecal incontinence on neurogenic or non-neurogenic basis, where transanal irrigation is indicated.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Morbus Hirschsprungs disease.
- Anorectal malformations.
- Use of medication that are known to cause constipation (e.g. anticholinergics)
